description:
The Issyk-Kul virus is a zoonotic virus that belongs to the genus Nairovirus, within the family Nairoviridae. It is named after the Issyk-Kul region in Kyrgyzstan, where it was first isolated from ticks of the genus Dermacentor in the 1970s.

The Issyk-Kul virus is an enveloped, negative-sense, single-stranded RNA virus. It is primarily transmitted by ticks, which serve as both the reservoir and vector for the virus. Humans can become infected through tick bites or by handling infected animals.

The virus has the ability to cause Issyk-Kul fever, a febrile illness characterized by sudden onset, headache, myalgia, and gastrointestinal symptoms. In severe cases, it can lead to hemorrhagic manifestations. The virus is considered a potential public health concern, particularly in regions where its primary vector, the Dermacentor tick, is present.

Ongoing research focuses on understanding the epidemiology, pathogenesis, and potential diagnostic and therapeutic interventions for Issyk-Kul virus infections. Proper tick control and personal protective measures are essential in areas where the virus is known to be present.
